--- title: smithwaterman keywords: fastai sidebar: home_sidebar summary: "API details." ---
{% raw %}

Preprocessing¶

words2ints[source]

words2ints(list_of_strings)

Map unique words to integer IDs

Obligatory example with Monty Python quotes¶

text = """Not much of a cheese shop is it
Finest in the district sir
And what leads you to that conclusion
Well it's so clean
It's certainly uncontaminated by cheese""".split('\n')

words2ints(text)

{'of': '0',
 'cheese': '1',
 'uncontaminated': '2',
 'sir': '3',
 'you': '4',
 'what': '5',
 'certainly': '6',
 'by': '7',
 'a': '8',
 'shop': '9',
 'to': '10',
 'it': '11',
 "It's": '12',
 'so': '13',
 'is': '14',
 'conclusion': '15',
 'district': '16',
 'that': '17',
 "it's": '18',
 'much': '19',
 'Well': '20',
 'leads': '21',
 'Finest': '22',
 'clean': '23',
 'Not': '24',
 'the': '25',
 'in': '26',
 'And': '27'}

traceback[source]

traceback(score_matrix, sequence_b, aligned_sequence=None, old_i=0)

Trace back the best alignments for subsequences of a and b sequences

matrix[source]

matrix(sequence_a, sequence_b, match_score=3, gap_cost=2)

Create a score matrix from the two sequences that we are aligning. Define the match score and gap cost, then fill the matrix. The gap cost is linear: delete and insert operations cost the same

smithwaterman[source]

smithwaterman(hypothesis, reference, match_score=3, gap_cost=2)

High-level function that implements SW alignment with linear gap cost. Returns all local alignments
